Parameters.Text:
Welcome back to MindTrails! Let's get started with practicing flexible thinking. 

Today, you will: answer a few questions about your anxiety, complete 3 scenarios that challenge you to come up with thoughts, feelings, and behaviors, and wrap-up with a Quick Thinking exercise. 

Let's get started!

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how anxious have you felt? 

0 = Most calm I could imagine being. 

10 = Most anxious, panicked, or scared I could imagine being.

Please touch the sliding bar to select your response, or press 'More options...'

Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much were you able to change the way you thought about things when you wanted to feel better. 

An example might be: If you were feeling worried about an upcoming test, were you able to remind yourself that you studied a lot and were prepared? 

0 = Not at all - I wasn't able to think in different ways to feel better. 

10 = Completely - I was totally able to think in different ways to feel better.

OtherChoices: I didn't want/need to change my feelings

Parameters.Text:
Thinking about the last 24 hours, how much did you try to stay away from or be less involved in situations that would make you anxious or scared? 

An example might be: If your teacher asked a question to the class and you knew the answer, do you not answer so you won't draw attention to yourself? 

0 = I tried to stay away from doing anything and everything that would make me anxious or scared. 

10 = If there was something that would make me anxious or scared, I pushed myself to do it anyway.

OtherChoices: Nothing happened that made me anxious

Parameters.Text: In this exercise, please think of an UPCOMING situation that you expect will make you feel anxious, worried, or scared. Pick a situation that you worry might go badly, or that you expect will bring on feelings of anxiety (like racing heart, sweating). Any situation that will make you feel quite anxious or scared will work, as long as it is a situation that is likely to actually happen.
Please describe the situation in a few words:

Please imagine the situation as vividly as possible (i.e., so that it feels very real). Try to imagine you are actually in the situation. Play out the specific parts of the situation in your head. Try to imagine using all your senses while you think about this situation. Think about the things you would see, hear, and smell if you were really in that situation. Think about the kinds of things you would think or feel if you were actually there.
Play this situation in your head for the next 20 seconds. The screen will change automatically after 20 seconds

How anxious did you feel (at the highest level of anxiety) as you completed the imagery task?  

0 = Absolutely no anxiety. 

10 = Totally anxious.
How vividly did you imagine the situation?
How likely is it that the situation; how likely is it that the task will turn out well versus turn out badly?

Buttons: Very likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out well
Somewhat likely to turn out badly
Very likely to turn out badly

Parameters.Text: If this situation did turn out badly, how well or badly would you be able to handle it?

Sections.Name: Domains
Sections.Description: The domains listed here are some areas that may cause teens to feel anxious. Please select the one that you'd like to work on during today's training.

Parameters.Text:
Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Click Next to see some thoughts.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: My guardian may ground me for doing badly in math, but I can handle it.
My teacher will say good things about me trying hard to learn.
I'm going to be in big trouble.
My teacher will tell my guardian how I'm doing in the class, and I'll be OK with that.
I am a good student, and my teacher will tell my guardian that.

Parameters.Text:
Now's your chance to be creative! What could you say to yourself to make you feel better in this situation?  

On the next page, please take 30 seconds to write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Please take 30 seconds to write different thoughts. The next button will appear automatically. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

During tonight's parent-teacher conference, your guardian is going to talk to your math teacher. You're not doing well in math, and you haven't told your guardian this yet. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I'm glad my guardian cares enough to go talk to my teacher.
I'm worried about what my teacher will say to my guardian.
I feel calm knowing that my guardian will love me no matter what my grade is.
I'm uneasy right now, but this feeling won't last forever.
I feel anxious thinking about the conversation, but I can focus on my homework until my guardian gets home.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

On the next page, take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I'll ask my teacher how to bring up my grade.
I won't hide in my room when my guardian gets home.
I don't want to ask my teacher for help, but I know that if I do, that'll be best in the long run.
I want to avoid talking to my guardian, but know it's better to get it out of the way when they get home.
I'll skip math tomorrow.

On the next page, please take 30 seconds to write as many different thoughts that you might have that would be helpful in this situation. You can use the thoughts that you saw a moment ago for inspiration, or can list things that you've told yourself in the past that have helped. 

What could you tell yourself in this situation that would help you feel less anxious or would help you handle your feelings of anxiety?

Press enter after each thought to write a new one on each line.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Please take 30 seconds to write different thoughts. The next button will appear automatically. 

Thoughts in the moment:
Great job! Now you'll see some feelings.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Here are some feelings that might happen in the moment:

Text: I feel anxious thinking about my parents not getting along, but remember that I can't do anything about it.
I'm angry that they're always arguing.
I feel confident that this will blow over fairly quickly.
I'm sad that they're arguing a lot, but know that I'm not the reason for it.
I'm glad I am able to remove myself from the situation.

Parameters.Text:
Now you try! What are some feelings that you could have in the moment? These don't have to only be feelings that you've had in the past or negative feelings that you assume you'd have in the moment. Think creatively about both positive and negative feelings that may come up for you in reaction to the situation. If you write a negative feeling, try to also write how you might cope with that feeling. 

On the next page, take 30 seconds to write as many different feelings that you could imagine having in this situation. You can be as creative as you want. If you write any negative feelings (like scared or anxious), try to also write how you could help yourself feel better in the moment.

Press enter after each feeling to write a new one on each line.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Please take 30 seconds to write different feelings. The next button will appear automatically. 

Feelings in the moment and how you'd handle any negative feelings:
Great job! Now you'll see some behaviors.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Here are some behaviors that someone might do at that moment or in the future:

Text: I want to storm off, but walk away calmly.
I walk away.
I yell at them to answer my question.
I give them some space and let my sad feelings pass.
I go do my homework.

Parameters.Text:
Your turn! Now it's up to you to write down as many behaviors as you can that might be helpful in the moment. Remember, avoiding or leaving the situation might feel better in the moment, but actually makes anxiety worse in the future! Try to think about behaviors that you can do in the moment that would allow you to stay in the situation. What could you do in the situation that allows you to push through anxiety?

On the next page, please take 30 seconds to write as many behaviors that you could do in the moment that would be helpful and make you feel less anxious in the future.

You notice your parents are upset with each other. They give you a short answer when you try to talk with them. 

Please take 30 seconds to write different behaviors. The next button will appear automatically.

Behaviors you might do in the moment:

Great job! You've completed the first of three training exercises. Next you'll do the same exercise with a new story. 

Again, the goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

Your guardian is dropping you off at your sports practice. As they drop you off, they are really loud and everyone on your team looks at you. 

Click Next to see some thoughts.

Your guardian is dropping you off at your sports practice. As they drop you off, they are really loud and everyone on your team looks at you. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: I'm looking forward to practice today.
I'm lucky to have a guardian who takes me to sports practice.
My friends don't want me on the team because of my guardian. But then I realize that thought isn't realistic.
My immediate thought is that my teammates will hate me, but I remind myself that I don't judge my friends for what their parents do.
My friends on the team are going to judge me.

Excellent work! Now you'll do a Quick Thinking exercise and then you'll be done for today.

Next, you're going to see a scenario that might make you anxious. As you read the short story, picture yourself in that situation. After you picture yourself in the situation, click "Next" and then you'll see examples of thoughts, feelings, and behaviors that might happen in that situation. 

Some of the thoughts, feelings, and behaviors will be helpful and some won't be.

The goal of this exercise is to help you learn that there are lots of different reactions that you might have in a scary situation, and not all of these thoughts, feelings, and behaviors have to be negative. 

After you see some thoughts, you'll be asked to write your own example of a helpful thought that you might have in that situation. You'll do the same thing for feelings and behaviors.
Picture yourself in the situation on the next page.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Click Next to see some thoughts.

You and your family are heading out of town for a few days and your parent asks you to double-check that all the appliances in your house are turned off before you leave. You had to rush to pack so didn't get to check everything. 

Here are some thoughts that might pop into mind:

Text: Even though I didn't get to fully check a second time before we all left, I'm pretty sure everything is off.
I think I may be responsible for a disaster, but realize I am overthinking.
I think about how I noticed during the first check everything was turned off.
I think I missed something that may have been left on.
I think everything is turned off.

You're out with friends and receive this message from your parent saying, "You need to come home right now."

What did I do wrong? 
 My parent has something really important to tell me. 
 I'm really tired, so I'm glad to be going home.
